texts.label: text
texts.orig: My curiosity is always piqued when I find new ways to manipulate command line output in simple ways. While working on a solution to parse /proc/mdstat output, I stumbled upon the  paste  utility.
texts.text: My curiosity is always piqued when I find new ways to manipulate command line output in simple ways. While working on a solution to parse /proc/mdstat output, I stumbled upon the  paste  utility.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The  man page  offers a very simple description of its features:
texts.text: The  man page  offers a very simple description of its features:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Write lines consisting of the sequentially corresponding lines from each FILE, separated by TABs, to standard output.
texts.text: Write lines consisting of the sequentially corresponding lines from each FILE, separated by TABs, to standard output.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Here's an example of how it works. Let's say you want to parse some software raid output that looks like this:
texts.text: Here's an example of how it works. Let's say you want to parse some software raid output that looks like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# mdadm --brief --verbose --detail /dev/md0
ARRAY /dev/md0 level=raid1 num-devices=2 metadata=00.90 UUID=7bea4601:d5a02f5c:2da69848:3184a367
   devices=/dev/sda1,/dev/sdb1
texts.text:
# mdadm --brief --verbose --detail /dev/md0
ARRAY /dev/md0 level=raid1 num-devices=2 metadata=00.90 UUID=7bea4601:d5a02f5c:2da69848:3184a367
   devices=/dev/sda1,/dev/sdb1

texts.label: text
texts.orig: It would be handy if we had both on one line as that would make it easier to parse with a script. Of course, you can do this with utilities like awk and tr, but paste makes it so much easier:
texts.text: It would be handy if we had both on one line as that would make it easier to parse with a script. Of course, you can do this with utilities like awk and tr, but paste makes it so much easier:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# mdadm --brief --verbose --detail /dev/md0 | paste - -
ARRAY /dev/md0 level=raid1 num-devices=2 metadata=00.90 UUID=7bea4601:d5a02f5c:2da69848:3184a367       devices=/dev/sda1,/dev/sdb1
texts.text:
# mdadm --brief --verbose --detail /dev/md0 | paste - -
ARRAY /dev/md0 level=raid1 num-devices=2 metadata=00.90 UUID=7bea4601:d5a02f5c:2da69848:3184a367       devices=/dev/sda1,/dev/sdb1

texts.label: text
texts.orig: By default, paste uses tabs to separate the lines, but you can use the
texts.text: By default, paste uses tabs to separate the lines, but you can use the

texts.label: text
texts.orig: argument to specify any delimiter you like:
texts.text: argument to specify any delimiter you like:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# mdadm --brief --verbose --detail /dev/md0 | paste -d"*" - -
ARRAY /dev/md0 level=raid1 num-devices=2 metadata=00.90 UUID=7bea4601:d5a02f5c:2da69848:3184a367*   devices=/dev/sda1,/dev/sdb1
texts.text:
# mdadm --brief --verbose --detail /dev/md0 | paste -d"*" - -
ARRAY /dev/md0 level=raid1 num-devices=2 metadata=00.90 UUID=7bea4601:d5a02f5c:2da69848:3184a367*   devices=/dev/sda1,/dev/sdb1
